bibl.title: Letter from Alfons Dampf to Philip Showalter Hench, February 27, 1942

div1.p: Dampf inquires about obtaining a copy of Cornwell's painting to show to his students. He comments on Hench's "Conquerors of Yellow Fever" article.

div1.head: Letter from Alfons Dampf to Philip Showalter Hench, February 27, 1942

DEPARTAMENTO DE ENTOMOLOGIA

“LELAND OSSIAN HOWARD”
Dr. P.S. Hench, Division of Medicine,
The Mayo Clinic, R o c h e s t e r, Minn., U.S.A.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I read with vivid interest your interesting address
“Conquerors of Yellow Fever”, published in the Proceedings
of the Staff Meetings of the Mayo Clinic", which I am receiving
thanks to the kind services of Dr. T.P. Magath. As I am lecturing
on Medical Entomology, I would like to know where a copy of
Dean Cornwell fine painting is obtainable, to show it to my stu-
dents. What you say about Lazear's death adds a thrilling note
to the story of the conquerors a yellow fever, very human indeed.

Excuse my inquiry, caused by the desire to stimulate
the students of our School to keep in their mind the words with
which you conclude your address: “to note the example of men
who banded together to die if need be for their fellow men of all
countries.”
